money-context.title: Your money
money-context.description:
We're going to ask if you've lost money as a result of the crime.

This will help us decide if you'll get a payment for expenses or loss of earnings.

offender-context.description:
We’re going to ask:

  • the offender's name (if you know it)
  • if you have contact with the offender

This is so we can make sure the offender does not benefit from any compensation you get.

We will never contact the offender.
offender-context.description_someone-else:
We’re going to ask:

  • the offender's name (if you know it)
  • if the victim has contact with the offender

This is so we can make sure the offender does not benefit from any compensation.

We will never contact the offender.

rep.adult:
We need proof so we know they have the right to apply on the victim's behalf.

This proof can be a certified copy of a:

  • power of attorney document they're named on
  • court order showing they have legal authority to act on behalf of the victim

Sending us certified documents

You must provide certified documentation when applying to us. This means it should be a photocopy of the original document that someone then certifies as a 'true copy'.

To certify a document as a true copy of the original document, you need to get it signed and dated by someone in a professional capacity - such as a solicitor.

Discover more information about certifying documents (opens in new tab) if you're still unsure about sending these to us.

If their name or the victim's name has changed, you'll have to show proof of this change.

We'll tell you how to send this at the end of the application.
rep.child:
We need proof so we know they have the right to apply on the victim's behalf.

This proof can be:

  • the victim's full birth certificate
  • adoption documents
  • a parental responsibility agreement
  • a court order showing they have parental responsibility, which means they have legal authority, for the victim

You can:

  • take or scan a photo and send it via email
  • send a photocopy of this to us via post

If their name or the victim's name has changed, you'll have to show proof of this change.

We'll tell you how to send this at the end of the application.
rep.adultNoLegalAuthority:
We need the details of the person with legal authority to act on behalf of the victim to begin processing this application. However, we understand this might not be confirmed as yet. Unfortunately, we're unable to progress the application any further until we have these details.

You can still submit this application today without providing these details. And then send this on to us at a later date.

This proof should be a certified copy of a:

  • power of attorney document they're named on
  • court order showing they have legal authority to act on behalf of the victim

Sending us certified documents

You must provide certified documentation when applying to us. This means it should be a photocopy of the original document that someone then certifies as a 'true copy'.

To certify a document as a true copy of the original document, you need to get it signed and dated by someone in a professional capacity - such as a solicitor.

Discover more information about certifying documents (opens in new tab) if you're still unsure about sending these to us.

We'll tell you more about this at the end of the application.

pregnancy-context.description:
We need to ask questions about pregnancy related to the crime. These questions may be difficult to answer or may not be relevant to you.

By answering them, it ensures you are considered for all correct compensation from us. This helps us better understand the case and if we need to ask for more evidence from you.

Help and support

The following links open in a new tab.

You can get practical and emotional support after a crime. Visit Victim and Witness information if you’re in England and Wales. Or support as a victim or witness of crime in Scotland.

We're going to ask for some details about your treatment

We'll use these to understand:

We often have to ask your GP or other health service provider for evidence about your injuries and treatment. We will let you know if we need to do this.

details-context.title: Your mental health
details-context.description:
We're going to ask how the crime affected your mental health.

This helps us decide if you'll get a payment for mental injury.

Disabling mental injury

We can only pay for a 'disabling mental injury' that:

  • makes it much harder to do things you would normally do
  • lasts six weeks or more
  • is confirmed by a diagnosis or prognosis by a clinical psychologist or psychiatrist

You can apply if you do not have a diagnosis yet. We'll tell you what medical evidence you'll need. This may be a copy of your medical record, a GP report or a specialist report.
details-context.description_someone-else:
We're going to ask how the crime affected their mental health.

This helps us decide if they get a payment for mental injury.

Disabling mental injury

We can only pay for a 'disabling mental injury' that:

  • makes it much harder to do things they would normally do
  • lasts six weeks or more
  • is confirmed by a diagnosis or prognosis by a clinical psychologist or psychiatrist

You can apply if they do not have a diagnosis yet. We'll tell you what medical evidence they'll need. This may be a copy of their medical record, a GP report or a specialist report.

compensation-context.description:
We're going to ask about any other compensation or damages you've been paid for your injuries from any other source.

This includes any compensation or damages you've not already received.

This is so we can work out how much compensation you may receive.
compensation-context.description_someone-else:
We're going to ask about any other compensation or damages the victim has been paid for their injuries from any other source.

This includes any compensation or damages they have not already received.

This is so we can work out how much compensation they may receive.

context-crime-impact.description:
We're going to ask you questions about:

  • how your daily life has been impacted by your injuries
  • how long the effects of your injuries are likely to last
  • your ability to work now and in future

The answers you give help build an understanding of how your injuries have affected you.

In sending this application, you will be considered for compensation for loss of earnings and special expenses.

Loss of earnings

If the medical evidence shows the injuries result in very limited or no capacity to work, you may get a loss of earnings payment.

Special expenses

If you cannot work for more than 28 weeks or are likely to lose earnings because of how severe the injuries are, or are incapacitated to a similar extent, you may receive a special expenses payment.

Both of these payment types are to compensate for any financial losses you have because of your injuries.
context-crime-impact.description_someone-else:
We're going to ask you questions about:

  • how the victim's daily life has been impacted by their injuries
  • how long the effects of their injuries are likely to last
  • their ability to work now and in future

The answers you give help build an understanding of how their injuries have affected them.

In sending this application, the victim will be considered for compensation for loss of earnings and special expenses.

Loss of earnings

If the medical evidence shows the injuries result in very limited or no capacity to work, they may get a loss of earnings payment.

Special expenses

If the victim cannot work for more than 28 weeks or is likely to lose earnings because of how severe the injuries are, or is incapacitated to a similar extent, they may receive a special expenses payment.

Both of these payment types are to compensate for any financial losses they have because of their injuries.

context-crime-impact.title: The impact the injuries have had

applicant-declaration.description:
You have told us that you are ||/answers/p-applicant-enter-your-name/q-applicant-title|| ||/answers/p-applicant-enter-your-name/q-applicant-first-name|| ||/answers/p-applicant-enter-your-name/q-applicant-last-name|| and you are applying on behalf of yourself.

By submitting this application, you confirm that you understand the following:

  • the information given in this application for compensation is true
  • Criminal Injuries Compensation Authority (CICA) may share and receive information with the following parties for the purposes of processing this application for compensation or verifying information provided:
    • police, prosecutors and ACRO Criminal Records Office, including for the purposes of obtaining a report of the crime and a record of any criminal convictions you may have
    • medical organisations, practitioners, and police medical staff to obtain medical evidence - including medical records and expert reports. CICA will let you know if this is required
    • any other individuals or organisations where necessary to process this application
    • any representative appointed to act for you in the course of this application
  • CICA must be notified immediately of any change in circumstances relevant to this application, including any change of address and information about any other claim or proceedings which may give rise to a separate award or payment in respect of your injuries

Providing wrong or misleading information

If untrue or misleading information is deliberately provided, compensation may be refused and the person(s) responsible may be prosecuted.

Read our privacy notice to see how we use your data (opens in new tab).

Information about appointing a legal or another representative

It is not necessary to appoint a legal or other representative to act on a victim’s behalf. If a representative is appointed at any stage, please be aware that:

  • CICA cannot meet their costs
  • we will only communicate directly with any appointed representative

If we make an award, we will pay it only to the victim or their legal representative. This is unless the application has been made on behalf of:

  • an adult who cannot manage their own financial affairs
  • a child who is under 18 years of age

It is our general policy to put an award for a child in an interest-earning deposit account until they reach the age of 18.

If a monetary award is to be made and there is a dispute about outstanding legal fees, it is our policy to retain the disputed amount until the dispute has been resolved.

If it is decided that a representative’s services are no longer required, CICA must be notified in writing as soon as possible.

rep-declaration.description:
You have told us that you are ||/answers/p-rep-name/q-rep-title|| ||/answers/p-rep-name/q-rep-first-name|| ||/answers/p-rep-name/q-rep-last-name|| and you are applying on behalf of ||/answers/p-applicant-enter-your-name/q-applicant-title|| ||/answers/p-applicant-enter-your-name/q-applicant-first-name|| ||/answers/p-applicant-enter-your-name/q-applicant-last-name|| (the victim).

By submitting this application, you confirm that you understand the following:

  • the information given in this application for compensation is true
  • Criminal Injuries Compensation Authority (CICA) may share and receive information with the following parties for the purposes of processing this application for compensation or verifying information provided:
    • police, prosecutors and ACRO Criminal Records Office, including for the purposes of obtaining a report of the crime and a record of any criminal convictions the victim may have
    • medical organisations, practitioners, and police medical staff to obtain medical evidence - including medical records and expert reports. CICA will let you know if this is required
    • any other individuals or organisations where necessary to process this application
    • any representative appointed to act for the victim in the course of this application
  • CICA must be notified immediately of any change in circumstances relevant to this application, including any change of address and information about any other claim or proceedings which may give rise to a separate award or payment in respect of the victim's Injuries

Providing wrong or misleading information

If untrue or misleading information is deliberately provided, compensation may be refused and the person(s) responsible may be prosecuted.

Read our privacy notice to see how we use your data (opens in new tab).

Information about appointing a legal or another representative

It is not necessary to appoint a legal or other representative to act on a victim’s behalf. If a representative is appointed at any stage, please be aware that:

  • CICA cannot meet their costs
  • we will only communicate directly with any appointed representative

If we make an award, we will pay it only to the victim or their legal representative. This is unless the application has been made on behalf of:

  • an adult who cannot manage their own financial affairs
  • a child who is under 18 years of age

It is our general policy to put an award for a child in an interest-earning deposit account until they reach the age of 18.

If a monetary award is to be made and there is a dispute about outstanding legal fees, it is our policy to retain the disputed amount until the dispute has been resolved.

If it is decided that a representative’s services are no longer required, CICA must be notified in writing as soon as possible.

se-context.title: Special expenses
se-context.description:
We’re going to ask you about specific payments you may have had to make, or will make, because of the injuries caused by the crime.

We can only consider certain expenses – known as “special expenses” – and will ask you questions about these.

We’ll consider this application for special expenses if the victim has experienced one of the following for more than 28 weeks due to their injuries:

  • lost earnings
  • lost earning capacity
  • or been incapacitated to a similar extent

The 28 weeks can be a single period of time or cover several periods of time since the crime. Any special expenses payment will include payment for the first 28 weeks from when they were injured.

Providing evidence of expenses

We may ask you to provide evidence:

  • of any expenses incurred or expected
  • that the products or services are not available free of charge
  • that they were needed as a result of the injuries

"})}}

mainapplicant-declaration.description:
You have told us that you are ||/answers/p-mainapplicant-enter-your-name/q-mainapplicant-title|| ||/answers/p-mainapplicant-enter-your-name/q-mainapplicant-first-name|| ||/answers/p-mainapplicant-enter-your-name/q-mainapplicant-last-name|| and you are applying on behalf of ||/answers/p-applicant-enter-your-name/q-applicant-title|| ||/answers/p-applicant-enter-your-name/q-applicant-first-name|| ||/answers/p-applicant-enter-your-name/q-applicant-last-name|| (the victim).

By submitting this application, you confirm that you understand the following:

  • the information given in this application for compensation is true
  • Criminal Injuries Compensation Authority (CICA) may share and receive information with the following parties for the purposes of processing this application for compensation or verifying information provided:
    • police, prosecutors and ACRO Criminal Records Office, including for the purposes of obtaining a report of the crime and a record of any criminal convictions the victim may have
    • medical organisations, practitioners, and police medical staff to obtain medical evidence - including medical records and expert reports. CICA will let you know if this is required
    • any other individuals or organisations where necessary to process this application
    • any representative appointed to act for the victim in the course of this application
  • CICA must be notified immediately of any change in circumstances relevant to this application, including any change of address and information about any other claim or proceedings which may give rise to a separate award or payment in respect of the victim’s Injuries

Providing wrong or misleading information

If untrue or misleading information is deliberately provided, compensation may be refused and the person(s) responsible may be prosecuted.

Read our privacy notice to see how we use your data (opens in new tab).

Information about appointing a legal or another representative

It is not necessary to appoint a legal or other representative to act on a victim’s behalf. If a representative is appointed at any stage, please be aware that:

  • CICA cannot meet their costs
  • we will only communicate directly with any appointed representative

If we make an award, we will pay it only to the victim or their legal representative. This is unless the application has been made on behalf of:

  • an adult who cannot manage their own financial affairs
  • a child who is under 18 years of age

It is our general policy to put an award for a child in an interest-earning deposit account until they reach the age of 18.

If a monetary award is to be made and there is a dispute about outstanding legal fees, it is our policy to retain the disputed amount until the dispute has been resolved.

If it is decided that a representative’s services are no longer required, CICA must be notified in writing as soon as possible.

help-reason-for-delay.description:
{% from "components/details/macro.njk" import govukDetails %}{{ govukDetails({summaryText: "Help with why we ask about the application not being sent until now",html: '

If the victim was an adult at the time of the crime (18 years or older)

The application must be sent as soon as is reasonably practicable and in any event, no later than 2 years after the crime.

If the victim was a child at the time of the crime (under 18 years old)

The application must be received:

  • on or before their 20th birthday, if the crime was reported to police before their 18th birthday
  • within 2 years of the crime first being reported to police, if the incident was reported on or after their 18th birthday

Extending the time limits

We can only extend the time limits where:

  • due to exceptional circumstances, the application could not be made earlier (for example, where injuries stopped the victim applying)

and

  • the evidence provided to support the application means it can be decided without further extensive enquiries

You may have to provide evidence to support any reason for a delay in applying. This evidence may include a letter from your GP or other medical professional.

Any evidence to support your application should:

  • show why this application could not have been made earlier and explain the entire period of the delay
  • provide us with enough information to make a decision on an application without the need for further extensive enquiries

'})}}
